Died May 16

Getty Images / Photo by Harry Langdon

Died May 16

LayoutNode.Content: By: Legacy Staff 5 months ago
LayoutNode.SRC:
By: Legacy Staff

5 months ago

LayoutNode.Content: Sammy Davis Jr. was an entertainment powerhouse, a true triple threat of talent. Sammy could sing, dance, act, and be funny, too. He started at age 3 in vaudeville performing with his father and Will Mastin in the Will Mastin Trio. He later became a member of the Rat Pack with Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin. He had a hit record in 1972 with "Candy Man." He also received a Springarn Medal from the NAACP for outstanding achievement. We remember his life today as well as the lives of other notable people who died this day in history.

We remember hislife today as well as the lives of other notablepeople who died this day in history.

LayoutNode.Content: 2015: Dean Potter , U.S. free climber and BASE jumper known for his solo ascents, dies at 43.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2015: Dean Potter, U.S. free climber andBASE jumper known for his solo ascents, dies at43.

LayoutNode.Content: 2013: Bernard Waber , U.S. children's book author who wrote "The House on East 88th Street" and "Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile," dies at 91.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2013: Bernard Waber, U.S. children's bookauthor who wrote "The House on East 88thStreet" and "Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile," dies at 91.

LayoutNode.Content: Waber debuted as an author in 1962 with "The House on East 88th Street," which introduced readers to the loveable Lyle, first spotted in a bathtub in an Upper East Side brownstone. Lyle's story continued in "Lyle Finds His Mother," "Lyle and the Birthday Party," and other works. Waber also wrote many non-Lyle books, such as "Ira Sleeps Over," in which a boy fears he'll be teased for bringing a favorite stuffed teddy bear to a friend's house.. Read more.
LayoutNode.SRC: Waber debuted as anauthor in 1962 with "TheHouse on East 88thStreet," which introducedreaders to the loveableLyle, first spotted in abathtub in an Upper EastSide brownstone. Lyle's story continued in "LyleFinds His Mother," "Lyle and the BirthdayParty," and other works. Waber also wrotemany non-Lyle books, such as "Ira Sleeps Over,"in which a boy fears he'll be teased for bringinga favorite stuffed teddy bear to a friend's house..Read more.

LayoutNode.Content: 2013: Dick Trickle , U.S. race car driver who was on the NASCAR circuit and was a successful short-track driver, dies at 71.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2013: Dick Trickle, U.S. race car driver whowas on the NASCAR circuit and was asuccessful short-track driver, dies at 71.

LayoutNode.Content: A short-track star from Wisconsin Rapids, Wisconsin, Trickle was believed to have won up to 1,000 races while inspiring hundreds of racers throughout the Midwest. Among them was Hall of Famer Rusty Wallace, a St. Louis native who toured the same Midwest circuit and raced Trickle down to the wire for the 1983 ASA championship. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: A short-track star fromWisconsin Rapids,Wisconsin, Trickle wasbelieved to have won upto 1,000 races whileinspiring hundreds ofracers throughout theMidwest. Among them was Hall of Famer RustyWallace, a St. Louis native who toured the sameMidwest circuit and raced Trickle down to thewire for the 1983 ASA championship. Read moreRead more

LayoutNode.Content: 2012: Chuck Brown , U.S. guitarist and singer who was called the Godfather of Go-go Music and had a hit song in 1979 with "Busting Loose," dies at 75.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2012: Chuck Brown, U.S. guitarist and singerwho was called the Godfather of Go-go Musicand had a hit song in 1979 with "Busting Loose,"dies at 75.

LayoutNode.Content: Thanks to Brown and his deep, gravelly voice, go-go music was uniquely identified with Washington, D.C. That's where he continued to play the city's club circuit to a loyal audience late in life. At the time of Brown's death, Mayor Vincent Gray said the city would be a different place without him. "Go-go is D.C.'s very own unique contribution to the world of pop music," he said. "Today is a very sad day for music lovers the world over." Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: Thanks to Brown and hisdeep, gravelly voice,go-go music wasuniquely identified withWashington, D.C. That'swhere he continued toplay the city's club circuitto a loyal audience late in life. At the time ofBrown's death, Mayor Vincent Gray said thecity would be a different place without him."Go-go is D.C.'s very own unique contribution tothe world of pop music," he said. "Today is avery sad day for music lovers the world over." Read more

LayoutNode.Content: ]2010: Hank Jones , U.S. jazz pianist who was honored with the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Award and performed with Ella Fitzgerald and Charlie Parker, dies at 91.
LayoutNode.SRC: ]2010: Hank Jones, U.S. jazz pianist who washonored with the National Endowment for theArts Jazz Masters Award and performed with Ella FitzgeraldElla Fitzgerald and Charlie Parker, dies at 91.

LayoutNode.Content: A tireless musician who performed his blend of swing and bebop until the end, Jones came from a family of jazz musicians who included brothers Thad, a trumpeter, composer, and arranger, and Elvin, a drummer known for the polyrhythmic beat that propelled John Coltrane's classic quartet. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: A tireless musician whoperformed his blend ofswing and bebop until theend, Jones came from afamily of jazz musicianswho included brothersThad, a trumpeter,composer, and arranger, and Elvin, a drummerknown for the polyrhythmic beat that propelledJohn Coltrane's classic quartet. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 2010: Ronnie James Dio , U.S. rock singer known best as the lead singer for the bands Rainbow, Dio, and Black Sabbath, the latter following the departure of Ozzy Osbourne, dies at 67.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2010: Ronnie James Dio, U.S. rock singerknown best as the lead singer for the bandsRainbow, Dio, and Black Sabbath, the latterfollowing the departure of Ozzy Osbourne, diesat 67.

LayoutNode.Content: Dio rose to fame in 1975 as the first lead singer of Rainbow, the heavy metal band put together by guitarist Ritchie Blackmore, who had just quit Deep Purple. Dio then replaced legendary vocalist Ozzy Osbourne in Black Sabbath in 1980 with the critically acclaimed album "Heaven and Hell," considered by many critics to be one of the finest heavy metal albums of all time. His on-again, off-again tenure with Black Sabbath touched off an intense debate among fans as to which singer constituted the true essence of the band – a discussion that lasted until his death. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: Dio rose to fame in 1975as the first lead singer ofRainbow, the heavymetal band put togetherby guitarist RitchieBlackmore, who had justquit Deep Purple. Diothen replaced legendary vocalist Ozzy Osbournein Black Sabbath in 1980 with the criticallyacclaimed album "Heaven and Hell," consideredby many critics to be one of the finest heavymetal albums of all time. His on-again, off-againtenure with Black Sabbath touched off anintense debate among fans as to which singerconstituted the true essence of the band – adiscussion that lasted until his death. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 2008: Robert Mondavi , U.S. winemaker who owned the internationally known Mondavi Winery in California, dies at 94.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2008: Robert Mondavi, U.S. winemaker whoowned the internationally known MondaviWinery in California, dies at 94.

LayoutNode.Content: Always convinced that California wines could compete with the European greats, Mondavi engaged in the first French-American wine venture when he formed a limited partnership with the legendary French vintner Baron Philippe de Rothschild to grow and make the ultrapremium Opus One at Oakville, California. The venture's first vintage, 1979, was released in 1984. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: Always convinced thatCalifornia wines couldcompete with theEuropean greats,Mondavi engaged in thefirst French-Americanwine venture when heformed a limited partnership with the legendaryFrench vintner Baron Philippe de Rothschild togrow and make the ultrapremium Opus One atOakville, California. The venture's first vintage,1979, was released in 1984. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 2001: Brian Pendleton , English guitarist who was an original member of the popular 1960s British band the Pretty Things, dies at 57.
LayoutNode.SRC: 2001: Brian Pendleton, English guitarist whowas an original member of the popular 1960sBritish band the Pretty Things, dies at 57.

LayoutNode.Content: 1993: Marv Johnson , U.S. singer-songwriter who was one of the first artists signed to Motown Records and had two top-10 singles, dies at 54.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1993: Marv Johnson, U.S. singer-songwriterwho was one of the first artists signed to Motown RecordsMotown Records and had two top-10 singles, dies at 54.

LayoutNode.Content: 1990: Jim Henson , U.S. puppeteer, artist, actor, and screenwriter who created the Muppets, dies at 53.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1990: Jim Henson, U.S. puppeteer, artist,actor, and screenwriter who created theMuppets, dies at 53.

LayoutNode.Content: While still in high school, Henson began working for a local television station in Maryland, creating puppets for a Saturday morning children's show. During college, he created a 5-minute puppet show called "Sam and Friends" for the local NBC affiliate in Washington, D.C. It was on this show that Kermit the Frog made his debut in 1955. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: While still in high school,Henson began workingfor a local televisionstation in Maryland,creating puppets for aSaturday morningchildren's show. Duringcollege, he created a 5-minute puppet showcalled "Sam and Friends" for the local NBCaffiliate in Washington, D.C. It was on this showthat Kermit the Frog made his debut in 1955. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 1990: Sammy Davis Jr. , U.S. singer, dancer, and actor who was a member of the Rat Pack with Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin and had a hit song in 1972 with "The Candyman," dies at 64.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1990: Sammy Davis Jr., U.S. singer, dancer,and actor who was a member of the Rat Packwith Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin and hada hit song in 1972 with "The Candyman," dies at64.

LayoutNode.Content: Davis was a performer all his life, beginning on vaudeville when he was just a 3-year-old. As he grew up and grew famous, he wowed us with his multifaceted talent: He could sing, dance, act, and do spot-on comic impressions – all with ease. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: Davis was a performerall his life, beginning onvaudeville when he wasjust a 3-year-old. As hegrew up and grewfamous, he wowed uswith his multifacetedtalent: He could sing, dance, act, and do spot-oncomic impressions – all with ease. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 1985: Margaret Hamilton , U.S. character actress known best for playing the Wicked Witch of the West in " The Wizard of Oz ," dies at 82.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1985: Margaret Hamilton, U.S. characteractress known best for playing the WickedWitch of the West in "The Wizard of Oz," dies at82.

LayoutNode.Content: 1984: Irwin Shaw , U.S. author, screenwriter and playwright known best for his novels "The Young Lions" and "Rich Man, Poor Man," dies at 71.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1984: Irwin Shaw, U.S. author, screenwriterand playwright known best for his novels "TheYoung Lions" and "Rich Man, Poor Man," diesat 71.

LayoutNode.Content: 1984: Andy Kaufman , U.S. actor, comedian, and performance artist known for his eccentric characters, such as Latka on the TV series "Taxi," and his feud with the wrestler Jerry "The King" Lawler, dies of lung cancer at 35.
LayoutNode.SRC: 1984: Andy Kaufman, U.S. actor, comedian,and performance artist known for his eccentriccharacters, such as Latka on the TV series"Taxi," and his feud with the wrestler Jerry "TheKing" Lawler, dies of lung cancer at 35.

LayoutNode.Content: Entertainer Kaufman – he preferred not to be called a comedian – was a familiar face on TV: a regular on the sitcom "Taxi" who also appeared several times on "Saturday Night Live." But his career was hardly in the mainstream. He told jokes without punch lines, performed acts without jokes, and elicited anger and boredom from audiences as often as laughter. He got onstage and read from "The Great Gatsby." He launched a professional wrestling career. He took an entire audience out for milk and cookies. Read more
LayoutNode.SRC: Entertainer Kaufman –he preferred not to becalled a comedian – wasa familiar face on TV: aregular on the sitcom"Taxi" who alsoappeared several timeson "Saturday Night Live." But his career washardly in the mainstream. He told jokes withoutpunch lines, performed acts without jokes, andelicited anger and boredom from audiences asoften as laughter. He got onstage and read from"The Great Gatsby." He launched a professionalwrestling career. He took an entire audience outfor milk and cookies. Read more

LayoutNode.Content: 1957: Eliot Ness , U.S. government agent known best for creating the law enforcement group in Chicago known as the Untouchables, who took down gangster Al Capone , dies at 54.

LayoutNode.Content: 1955: James Agee , U.S. author, journalist, and screenwriter who was one of the most influential film critics in the 1940s, co-wrote the movie The African Queen, and penned the novel "A Death in the Family," dies at 45.

LayoutNode.Content: 1953: Django Reinhardt , Belgian-born French jazz guitarist who was regarded as one of the greatest guitar players of all time, who performed with Louis Armstrong and Dizzy Gillespie , dies at 43.
